newsitem.title: CHINA: China's First Auto sets 2.0 bln yuan A share offer.
newsitem.headline: China's First Auto sets 2.0 bln yuan A share offer.

text.p: China's state-run First Auto Works plans to issue 300 million A shares for domestic investors in an offer that will raise more than 2.0 billion yuan ($240 million), the official Xinhua news agency said on Monday.
The company will begin offering the shares on Thursday. The shares are eventually to be listed on the nation's southern stock exchange in Shenzhen near Hong Kong.
Xinhua did not give a date for the listing of the shares and did not say who the underwriters would be.
Xinhua said the issue would be the biggest capital raising exercise involving the Shenzhen stock exchange.
First Auto would use the funds to expand production of its Hongqi, or Red Flag, sedan to 90,000 units a year by the 2001, Xinhua said.
Xinhua quoted the company as saying it was setting up a new manufacturing arm to handle the expanded production.
First Auto's output capacity of Red Flags was now 30,000 cars a year but the firm only made 11,000 units in 1996, Xinhua said. First Auto hoped output would reach 25,000 vehicles this year.
First Auto has a joint venture with Volkswagen AG at its plant in Changchun to produce Jettas.
The Chinese firm also had a licensing agreement with the Audi arm of Volkswagen to produce the Audi 100 model. That agreement expired in 1996.
Volkswagen has said the Red Flag, which uses a Chrysler Corp engine, is based on the Audi 100.
Xinhua said the Red Flag was China's only copyrighted, domestic-made car model developed by First Auto, but gave no other details.
Audi officials had previously said they hoped to boost Audi's car production in China to 90,000 units a year from 25,000 units by the end of the century.
